TALK.START.PARA: —The Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances was concerned about the effects of retrospectivity in the Student Regulations and the implications for students' rights to assistance of certain references to the Higher School Certificate course. The Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) has assured the Committee that the retrospectivity will cause no prejudice. She has also explained the reference to HSC courses and satisfied the Committee that certain students' rights to assistance are provided for in the Regulations. SPEECH.PARA: In the Fisheries Levy Regulations, the Committee noted that previous regulations imposing a $10 levy were being retrospectively corrected to reduce the levy to $5. The Regulations amounted to validation of a prima-facie unlawful collection of a lesser amount of fishing levy than the Regulations had provided for. That lesser amount, however, was consistent with the policy of the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) which had not been properly reflected in the Regulations; hence the need to correct them. The Minister assured the Committee that no levy other than the lesser amount had been collected and that no individual had been prejudiced by the retrospectivity. Consistent with the Committee's usual practice of keeping the Senate informed of its scrutiny activity, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the Committee's brief exchange of correspondence with the Ministers.
Leave granted.
The documents read as follows-
Senator the Hon. Susan Ryan
Minister for Education
Parliament House
Canberra, A.C.T. 2600
Dear Minister,

At its meeting on 19 February 1987 the Committee considered the Student Assistance Regulations (Amendment) (being Statutory Rules 1986 No. 381) which amend the Principal Regulations to implement the provisions of ``Austudy''. The Committee would be grateful if you could clarify two matters.

Firstly, parts of the Regulations are made retrospective and it appears that no one other than the Commonwealth is prejudiced by this. Could you, however, confirm that the Geelong Business Academy, which is retrospectively deleted by regulation 42 from the Schedule 3 list of technical and further education institutions for student assistance purposes, in fact ceased to exist prior to 30 April 1986?

Secondly, new paragraph 29 (4e) (b) inserted by regulation 7 (on page 8), provides for the interpretation of an expression which has not previously been adequately defined, namely ``the normal full-time amount of work of the course for a year''. In relation to the work of an approved secondary course in paragraph 29 (4e) (b) ``the normal full-time amount of work'' is defined as 10 annual units where the course is designed to prepare students for the HSC in the ACT or NSW. The Committee would appreciate your clarification of this reference to the HSC in the ACT, where, as the Committee understands it, that course is not extensively pursued in deference to the ACT Year 12 Certificate. The latter does not appear to be referred to in the Regulations.

As you appreciate, the Regulations are extremely intricate and complex. Thus, the Committee seeks your expert advice on the implications of this new paragraph and the comparative status of ACT Year 12 Certificate students and ACT HSC students.
Your sincerely,
BARNEY COONEY
Chairman
Dear Barney,
Thank you for your letter of 24 February 1987 requesting clarification of two aspects of Statutory Rules 1986 No. 381.
Geelong Business Academy ceased to operate on 29 April 1986 owing to the ill health of the Principal.

The second aspect concerns secondary studies in the ACT. Students undertaking matriculation studies at TAFE colleges in the ACT attempt the NSW Higher School Certificate examination. The ACT Year 12 Certificate applies to secondary schools only. The workload situation of secondary students at secondary schools is covered by regulation 44g. Such students are either full-time or not full-time.

On the other hand students undertaking courses at tertiary education institutions may receive living allowance if they are undertaking three-quarters or more of the normal full-time workload. Paragraph 29 (4e) (b) provides a workload reference point for students undertaking matriculation studies at TAFE colleges in the ACT and NSW.
Yours sincerely
SUSAN RYAN
Senator Barney Cooney
Chairman
Senate Standing Committee on
Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
Canberra, A.C.T. 2600
The Hon. John Kerin, M.P.
Minister for Primary Industry
Parliament House
Canberra, A.C.T. 2600
Dear Minister,

At its meeting on 19 February 1987 the Committee considered the Fisheries Levy (Northern Prawn Fishery) Regulations (Amendment), being Statutory Rules 1986 No. 397, which prescribed units of fishing capacity and amounts of levy. The Committee seeks your comments on the effects of the retrospectivity in the Regulations.

Regulation 3 amends regulation 6 and provides that the amount of levy imposed by certain paragraphs of the Fisheries Levy Act 1984 on the allocation or renewal of certain prescribed units of fishing capacity is $5 or $10 depending on the number of Class A units of fishing capacity determined under the plan of management in relation to a boat.

The accompanying Explanatory Statement explains that although the intention behind the original regulation 6 was to impose levy at the rate of $5 for each Class A unit of a boat with no more than 375 Class A units, the levy in fact provided by the regulations for pre-existing licence holders was $10 for each Class A unit. It appears that in practice relevant levy was collected at the rate of $5 per unit. Thus, as the Explanatory Statement notes, the regulations were contrary to the intention of the levy policy and the levy collection practice was contrary to the terms of the regulations. The retrospectivity in the new regulations is, of course, designed to validate the previous collection of the lower levy in breach of the requirements of the regulations as they then stood.

The Committee notes the comment in the Explanatory Statement that ``the retrospective operation of the amendment does not impose any additional liability upon persons who paid a lower rate of levy in 1986 than was prescribed at the time''. In this connection, the Committee seeks your advice on whether any relevant person in fact paid levy at a rate higher than $5. Also, perhaps you could let the Committee know if your legal advisers have considered the question whether the $5 levy collected prior to the coming into force of the latest amendment was in law collected illegally so that the regulations are in fact a retrospective validation of those illegal collections. If this were the case then the retrospectivity could be viewed as prejudicial to certain individuals.
The committee would appreciate your comments and advice on these matters.
Yours sincerely,
BARNEY COONEY
Chairman
Senator B. Cooney
Chairman
Senate Standing Committee on
Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA
Dear Senator Cooney,

I refer to your letter of 24 February 1987, seeking my advice about matters raised by the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances in relation to the Fisheries Levy (Northern Prawn Fishery) Regulations (Amendment) (Statutory Rules 1986 No. 397).

You ask whether any person whom the levy policy would have required to pay the concessional rate of levy of $5.00 per Class A unit in relation to the licensing year beginning on 1 March 1986 did in fact pay the full rate of levy, ie, $10.00 per Class A unit. No person paid other than the concessional rate on the allocation of Class A units that were simultaneously assigned to a boat for which the appropriate number of such units was fewer than 375. This was in accordance with the levy policy.

You also ask whether the collection of levy at the concessional rate prior to commencement of the above amendments was illegal and whether the amendment is ``a retrospective validation of those illegal collections''.

My view is that no levy was collected illegally, that is, no levy was collected contrary to the existing policy and authority for collection. However, it may reasonably be said that levy representing the difference between the concessional rate and the full rate was not collected in a number of cases. If there was any ``illegal'' action, it was the assigning of the relevant Class A units to boats before the full amount of levy, as the regulations then prescribed, was paid on the allocation of those Class A units to the holders.

It is correct to say that the end purpose of the amendment of regulation 6 is to validate those assignments retrospectively. Your Committee has already noted the reasons for this, as set out in the Explanatory Statement accompanying the Regulations. I fail to see, however, in what way the retrospectivity might have been prejudicial to any individual. No unit holder paid more levy than the levy policy intended. No unit holder will be required to pay additional levy as the result of retrospective application of the regulations for bringing the rate of levy, imposed on the allocation of Class A units that were simultaneously assigned to boats of fewer than 375 Class A units, into conformity with the levy policy in relation to those units and with the collections of levy that actually took place.
I trust that the above comments will allay the Committee's concerns.
Yours fraternally
JOHN KERIN

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee is considering clause 8 of the Bill. The question is that clause 8 stand as printed. When we finished last night there was an outstanding question. Does the Minister wish to answer it at this point?

—Who will determine whether a person is able to get some compensation, particularly when that person is slightly removed and has not obviously had some loss? Who will be the determining people, and will they err on the side that helps people in the need they will obviously have?

—Order! Before I call the next speaker, let me say that I think Senator Sanders was correct in his view. Clause 19 more accurately covers the subject of recent debate. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to refer back to the matter relating to costings. I believe that this is an inappropriate use of the Advance to the Minister for Finance. I remind the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) that the Advance to the Minister for Finance is a provision authorised by the annual Appropriation Act and made available to the Minister. I also remind the Minister that as a general principle the only amounts which would remain as a charge to the appropriations for the Advance to the Minister for Finance at the end of the financial year are those that are urgent and unforeseen. I believe that the Minister cannot claim that the setting up of a commission has been unforeseen. One could hardly say that it was urgent. It might be urgent in the Minister's mind, but this program has been around for quite some time.

SPEECH.PARA: There are other items in the annual appropriations that were examined the other night that made provisions for future commissions and for future consultants to be appointed. I refer to the Constitutional Reform Commission, for which an amount of $200,000 was set aside to cover such a contingency for advertising. I remind the Minister that funding under the Advance to the Minister for Finance should be for urgent and unforeseen expenditure. These expenditures, I submit, are foreseen. One cannot say that they are unforeseen because the legislation deliberately sets up a commission of three persons which will operate for up to 12 months. Therefore, the Government should have been able to put some sort of cost figures on the matter.

The Minister will be aware that annual circulars are issued to departments which outline the procedures and emphasise the requirements for departments to ensure that their applications in relation to the Advance to the Minister for Finance contain, or are appropriately supported by, sufficient detail to demonstrate that the requests comply with the urgent and unforeseen criterion. I submit that such requests under these circumstances could not meet the criterion which is set out each year in annual circulars issued by the Department of Finance. The Government is trying to use a backdoor method of financing this Commission rather than using the normal appropriations which can be foreseen and estimated with a reasonable degree of accuracy. If it can be done in other areas, I submit that it should have been done in these circumstances. Departments are required to submit adequately supported applications for funds to the Department of Finance. So I would have hoped that this documentation could be properly supported. I believe that the Minister is inappropriately using this mechanism of the Advance to the Minister for Finance rather than the normal appropriations, which should have been before this Parliament in the form of the estimates in recent days. TALK.START.PARA: —At this stage I have nothing to add to the advice already given to the Committee, which is that it is not practice to seek appropriations for matters arising out of legislation which has not yet been enacted. —Oh!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to draw attention to the responsibility of the Commission of Inquiry under clause 8-the functions clause-and ask whether, in inquiring into and reporting on the matters as set out in that clause, the Commission will have access to the following documents: A cablegram to various departments from the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation dated 25 June 1982; minutes of a meeting of the Australian National Commission for UNESCO of 17 September 1982; an undated draft letter to the Tasmanian Premier from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke); a letter to the Department of Foreign Affairs from the World Heritage Committee dated 1 September 1982? TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the Commission will be enabled to call for documents that it may require. If it requires these documents it will be able to call for them and receive them.
—Am I to understand from that that there is one rule for senators and another rule for commissions of inquiry when it comes to the Freedom of Information Act?

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 7, subclause 13 (1), line 14, after `1902', insert `(other than sections 6a and 6dd of that Act)'.
(2) Page 7, after subclause 13 (3), insert the following new subclauses:

`(1a) It is a reasonable excuse for the purposes of subsection (1) for a person to refuse to answer any question that the answer might tend to incriminate the person.'.'.

In response to Senator Sanders, I point out that Tasmanian senators in this chamber have every right to debate this Bill as hard as they wish. The Commonwealth Government is seeking to ride roughshod over a State and over an industry which is of vital consequence to the people of Tasmania. Not only will employment possibly be jeopardised now but it certainly will be in the future. I recall saying during my speech in the second reading debate that people are waiting to invest, particularly in value added industries associated with the forest industry in Tasmania. Tasmanians have every right to fight as hard as they are. It is a nonsense for another senator from Tasmania to seek to put them down in any way, shape or form. In our amendments to clause 13 we are picking up the recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, from which I quote:
The Committee has been critical of such provisions-
and in times past, I might add-

which remove the right to refuse to answer questions or produce documents on grounds of self incrimination but which confer protection in subsequent proceedings only in respect of the use of the actual answer given or document produced.

This has obviously been raised previously by the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. It is operating under the Royal Commissions Act 1902 and the Opposition has taken up the Scrutiny of Bills Committee's recommendations and put them into amendments. That is why we are moving them at this stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am a member of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. I must say that in the hearings the Committee has had since I have been a member I have been impressed by the usually quite sedate language that its reports have been couched in. I draw to this Committee's attention the criticism which the Scrutiny of Bills Committee has seen fit to make of clause 13. It is uncharacteristic of that Committee to speak in this language. It is very important to note that on this piece of legislation which we, in Tasmania anyway, believe is of such importance the Committee said that the Minister's response to the concerns which the Committee had already expressed about clause 13, `Self incrimination', suggests:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . that the present Bill has been thrown together in a hasty and slipshod fashion with more concern for ensuring that the Commission is enabled to operate `satisfactorily' than for the consequences of applying, in a blanket fashion, provisions of the Royal Commissions Act 1902 which may be wholly inappropriate to the nature of the Commission's inquiry.

The Committee insisted that by applying sections of the Royal Commissions Act 1902 which remove the `privilege against self incrimination to the inquiry it may be considered to trespass unduly on personal rights and liberties' of the citizen. In view of this damning report from the Scrutiny of Bills Committee I have to ask: Does the Government intend to take any action to stop trespassing on personal rights and liberties of the citizen? Will the Government accept our amendments? They are perfectly in tune with the recommendations of the Committee.

The Committee drew attention to the fact that section 6a of the Royal Commissions Act 1902 provides that `self-incrimination is not to be an excuse for the refusal or failure to produce a document or to answer questions as required by the Commission'. Section 6dd further provided that `a statement or disclosure made by a witness in giving evidence is not admissible against the witness in subsequent civil or criminal proceedings'. In the view of that Committee report, the protection should extend to any information or thing obtained as a direct or indirect consequence of the giving of the answer or of the production of the document.

The right to refuse to give answers to questions where it may result in a person being required to incriminate himself or herself is one of the most important protections available at common law. It should not be taken away lightly. So let us not forget that the Committee was so concerned about the right of the citizen being removed in this situation that it used quite uncharacteristic language in drawing the Senate's attention to the need for amendment to this legislation. As a result of the Government ignoring the Committee's report we in the Opposition have decided that we must take action in this area and produce the amendments which the shadow Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, Senator Collard, has just moved. I urge the Minister to have the Government take these amendments on board because if this legislation is passed, which due to the perfidy of the Australian Democrats seems likely, it at least should provide some basic protections for the citizen.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which I direct to the Minister for Finance, follows a question asked yesterday by Senator Chaney which referred to reports in the Press that the Government is considering selling off a large number of government enterprises, including the Overseas Telecommunications Commission, Aussat Pty Ltd, the Australian Industry Development Corporation, the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, Australian Airlines and Qantas Airways Ltd-at least that is what the reports say. What net economic benefits would flow from the sale of these enterprises, given any reduction in the public sector borrowing requirement which would result from their sale would be offset by private sector borrowing, almost certainly overseas borrowing, in order to finance their purchase? Further, does the Minister agree that the sale of these enterprises would be consistent with this Government's overall reliance on a deregulated market, even where this conflicts with party policy and results in policy indistinguishable from that which would be pursued by the Opposition if it were ever to win government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to the last part of the question, though not the last line, there is no correlation necessarily or indeed any correlation in practice between public ownership and regulation or deregulation. As I pointed out yesterday when replying to Senator Chaney, the Thatcher Government in England has sold off public assets and formerly publicly-owned business enterprises while simultaneously increasing the degree of regulation. So both in principle and in practice in some countries at least recently there is necessarily no correlation at all between regulation or deregulation and public ownership.

ANSWER.PARA: Turning to the first part of the question, consistent with what I have been saying for two years or more, I will not confirm or deny whatever rumour the Press Gallery is running today or yesterday, whether the rumour was generated by the Press Gallery itself or fed to it by somebody from outside. The central part of the question concerned what net economic benefits would flow from the sale of government enterprises. There is no simple answer to that. But the point ought to be made that if government property, whether it be real property like land or buildings or whether it be a publicly-owned trading enterprise, is not returning a yield on its value at least equal to the market rate of interest, the sale of such a property would obviously yield short term gains. However, it would also yield ongoing benefits to the public and to the Budget because the public debt would be reduced by an amount commensurate to its sale compared with what it would otherwise have been and the public debt interest obligation in perpetuity likewise would be reduced.

Senator Haines also mentioned overseas borrowing and so on. Well, somebody-no matter who; whether it is the Government or some private source-as long as we are running a current account deficit, must borrow from overseas to match that deficit. The final point is that the Australian Government does own assets overseas as well as in Australia and, if the continued ownership of those assets cannot be justified in economic terms, there are very clear gains to the country, from every point of view, in disposing of those assets.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Finance. What has been the impact of the decision in 1983 to modify the income equalisation deposits scheme for farmers? Does the Government accept that this decision has reduced lending moneys available to the Primary Industry Bank of Australia Ltd by about $150m per annum, as well as denying farmers the ability to smooth out their tax burdens should farm incomes show a significant improvement? ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find it somewhat ironic that Senator Brownhill should refer to the income equalisation deposits scheme enabling farmers to smooth out their taxable income, because the plain fact is that when John Howard was Treasurer and the National Party of Australia was last governing Australia the income equalisation deposits scheme had been corrupted by changes to the tax averaging provisions introduced by the Fraser Government and John Howard at the insistence of the National Party in the late 1970s. It enabled farmers to opt in or out of the tax averaging provisions at will.

ANSWER.PARA: I will not go into all the technical details because they are too complicated, but the plain fact is that, because of that corrupt change introduced by John Howard at the insistence of the National Party, there was a positive incentive for farmers to destabilise their taxable incomes by putting money into income equalisation deposits in years of low income and drawing it out in years of high income. So the income equalisation deposits scheme in its corrupt form, as last practised by John Howard on the instructions of the National Party, had an effect which was the reverse of that which it was supposed to have.

As for the Primary Industry Bank, again at the insistence of the National Party, when John Howard was Treasurer a pea and thimble trick was pulled under which money was made available from income equalisation deposits. At one stage I think the interest rate paid on the depo-sits was 5 per cent and the money was lent out at the same rate. The pea and thimble trick, of course, was that this was some costless way of providing money to the farm sector at below commercial rates of interest. Of course, it was not costless. Moreover, to the extent that that money was made available to the Primary Industry Bank to make soft loans, sometimes at sub-commercial interest rates, it fed the land price speculation boom of the late 1970s and the early 1980s and encouraged many farmers to buy land at excessive prices, which is the direct reason for a significant number of them being insolvent today. In other words, from any aspect at all, the income equalisation deposits, both in principle and in effect, as practised by John Howard when the National Party was last the de facto government of Australia, operated to the disadvantage of the farm sector and the country as a whole.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Treasurer whether the Government is aware of a report detailing major concerns about Queensland's economic performance. Can the Minister say whether the claims in the report are substantially correct? Can he also tell the Senate where the report emanates from?

—I am aware of a quite large report dealing with Queensland's economic performance under the Petersen Government. It is 23 pages in all. I am sure that Senator Chaney quite justifiably would complain if I were to read out the whole 23 pages during Question Time. The report emanates from the office of the Leader of the National Party of Australia, Mr Sinclair. I table the 23-page document.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs able to inform the Senate of the direct cost to the Commonwealth involved in transporting, accommodating and promoting Mr Oliver Tambo, the leader of the self-professed terrorist organisation the African National Congress, and his entourage on their visit to Australia?
—Cut it out. What nonsense are you talking?

—He is the self-professed leader of a terrorist organisation. Can the Minister also inform the Senate of the estimated cost of the security arrangements for this visit, and also the cost of the security arrangements for his visit to Nareen this weekend?

—I will refer the detailed questions about cost to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Once again, I take the opportunity to reject forcefully and unequivocally the kind of description that Senator Jessop insists on applying to Oliver Tambo and the African National Congress. Of course, violence has been perpetrated in South Africa by blacks-some of them under the auspices of the ANC-in responding to the system of oppression in that country. But I think an admirable statement of the context in which that has occurred, the reasons and, to the extent that it can be justified, the justification for it has been made by Mr Tambo during his visit in his public speeches, in particular, to the National Press Club. It is grotesquely insensitive for people like Senator Jessop to continue to malign this gentleman and the movement he stands for in the unthinking and crude way which has become all too common in this place.

—My question relates in part to the previous question that was asked of Senator Gareth Evans. I refer the Minister representing the Attorney-General to the repulsive and, I might add, very expensive full-page advertisement in a major Australian newspaper yesterday concerning the visit of the African National Congress leader, Oliver Tambo. The advertisement appears under the authorship of a group calling itself the International Freedom Foundation, which is apparently dedicated to harassing Mr Tambo wherever he travels. Does the Minister have any information about this group or, more importantly, who is really behind it? Does he consider such a development a healthy contribution to the world-wide concern and debate over the future of apartheid in South Africa? Given the further publicity in today's newspaper and, I understand, also on a morning television program about the gentleman who proclaims that he represents the International Freedom Foundation, what action will the Government take to ensure that if Mr Geoff Pandin does open an information office in Australia he operates it in accordance with the laws of Australia and not with the laws of gay abandon?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the case that an organisation calling itself the International Freedom Foundation took out a full page advertisement in the Australian on 2 April which was critical of the ANC and Mr Tambo in particular. That is a considerable understatement, I suppose, because it is a grotesque and repulsive advertisement, as Senator Coleman said. At this stage there is very little public information available about the IFF. Press reports today claim that it was founded six months ago in the United States by a Mr Jack Abramoff and has since established offices in Tel Aviv, London and Johannesburg, and has plans to establish an office in Melbourne. A visiting United States citizen, Mr Pandin, who has taken part in demonstrations in Australia against Mr Tambo's visit, is reportedly a spokesman for this organisation.

ANSWER.PARA: The background to Mr Tambo's visit and the auspices under which he is in Australia have been frequently stated by the Foreign Minister, and by me in this place. He is in Australia at the invitation of the Foreign Minister to put his views to the Australian public on an issue of major international importance-the future of southern Africa. People do, of course, have the right to express their views freely, and that would be the overriding consideration in any government reaction to the opening of an office by this organisation in Australia and the behaviour of spokesmen for it. The advertisement taken out by the IFF obviously does not contribute to serious, constructive or dispassionate debate about the future of black political rights in South Africa of the kind that this Government seeks to foster. We would deplore contributions to the debate that continue to be made in such strident and emotional terms. Of course, it will be the case that such an operation would have to be maintained within the law as it presently stands. While I do not imagine that the Government will take any special steps in this respect to oversight what is going on in respect of this organisation, clearly, if there is any question of it stepping beyond the bounds of the law, the Government will react accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. Is it a fact that there are still many beds closed at repatriation hospitals around Australia at this time? Is it true that, while some of the closures are due to reconstruction work, many are due to industrial disputations and a lack of sufficient nursing staff? Will the Minister advise the Senate of the steps he is taking to ensure that a maximum number of beds are made operational in all of the repatriation hospitals around Australia to take care of veterans, many of whom are entering critical phases of their lives?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find the question from Senator Bjelke-Petersen very unusual, having regard to the fact that there is a critical shortage of beds in the Queensland hospital system. There must surely be some concern about that particular problem. It places tremendous pressure upon my department which is required by law to provide treatment and hospital beds for entitled veterans. On occasions this results in the hospital at Greenslopes, Queensland, admitting an unusually large number of community patients, thus creating difficulties for the hospital whose main purpose is to provide accommodation and treatment for entitled veterans.

ANSWER.PARA: The only problem I have about repatriation beneficiaries in the hospitals is the acute shortage of trained nurses. Of course, the Opposition parties, which do not believe in intervention in the economy at all, can accept part of the blame for giving insufficient attention over past years to training opportunities for women who want to enter the nursing service. There is no way that this Government can be blamed for that acute shortage of trained personnel. In the light of that difficulty, of course I have problems in our providing every hospital with sufficient trained staff so that our requirements are met. We have taken steps. For example, we went to the United Kingdom in the early part of 1986 to recruit, through the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, a number of English nurses to accommodate the problem. No problem can be traced back to the Department or to the Repatriation Commission in these areas. We are grappling with a difficult problem, that of not having sufficient trained staff. We have other resources-beds and medicos-but we are not always able to provide sufficient trained staff to meet the need.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the Australian Bureau of Statistics figures on industrial disputes which were released yesterday? If the Minister has seen these statistics, can he indicate what light these figures shed on the effectiveness of the Hawke Government's policies in the industrial relations area?

—I have seen the most recent ABS figures on industrial disputes. They show that the total number of working days lost in the 1986 calendar year was 1,390,000. By contrast, the figure in 1982-the last year of the Fraser-Howard Government-was 2,158,000. In other words, a 75 per cent larger number of working days were lost because of industrial disputes. Mr Willis pointed out yesterday that over the past three years the average annual working days lost per thousand employees was 240, compared with an annual average of 590 during the Fraser-Howard Government years. The figure for the period of this Government is less than half it was during the period of the Fraser-Howard Government. That is one of the factors which demonstrate the success of the incomes policy-the accord-which the Government has implemented over the last four years. It is in contrast to both the record of the previous Government and the intention of the present Opposition-should it ever be elected to government. It is the clearly stated intention-stated with some relish, I might say-of the present Leader of the Opposition to have five years of industrial warfare.
—Has the Minister representing the Minister for Defence any information to give the Senate about the circumstances surrounding the tragic loss of an F111 aircraft last night?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The only information I have from the Minister so far is in the following terms: At 1939 hours last night, 2 April, F111 A8-128 crashed five miles north of Tenterfield, New South Wales, while on a low level night flight. The planned track was from East Sale to Amberley with a practice attack against a target in the Tenterfield area. The instructor pilot and student navigator were both killed.

ANSWER.PARA: A second F111 was about eight miles behind the accident aircraft and its crew had visual contact with its lights. As they approached Tenterfield the second crew saw a flash ahead which they saw as a fire when they passed over the site. While the extent of the damage to the ground caused by the impact and post-impact fire has not been fully evaluated, it is believed that neither people were injured, nor buildings damaged. No distress call was given by the accident aircraft. A Royal Australian Air Force board of inquiry has been appointed.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce relates to the report of the Inglis Committee of Review on Government High Technology Purchasing Arrangements which has been publicly released and is currently being considered by the Government. Given that there have been allegations put by some sectors of the business and trade union communities that government agencies have shown bias against the purchase of Australian products, is there any evidence being proffered to substantiate the claims? Does the Minister accept the allegations? When will the Government respond to the report?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure that `bias' is the correct word. It may be appropriate, but it may be too strong a word to describe the purchasing habits of some government departments which have developed over a number of years. I think those purchasing habits reflected a general tendency in the Australian community to rely on exports of raw materials as the salvation of this country and to consider that imports of equipment and machinery were of better quality. Also, there were significant incentives in some departments to purchase from overseas. For example, duty is not paid on equipment purchased from overseas and there are, of course, trips to be had for purchasing officers to purchase equipment overseas which would not be available to them if equipment was purchased in Australia. I am just saying that these general environmental factors have probably influenced the habits of certain departments.

ANSWER.PARA: Some of these concerns led the Government to set up the Inglis Committee of Review to recommend action to enable Australian suppliers, particularly of high technology products, to compete on an equitable basis with overseas suppliers of government purchases. Government orders can provide valuable initial markets for high technology firms, enabling them to develop products which are competitive on world markets. Some people who are advocates of an entirely free market should examine, for example, the situation in the United States where the defence budget is an enormous supporter of high technology companies and research and development in the United States. Also, the Buy American Act is an Act which is frequently invoked in support of local manufacturers in the United States. I am not suggesting that we should necessarily follow that track; I am just making a point about what happens in other countries. Government purchasing can play a significant role in industry development. The report of the Inglis Committee, chaired by Sir Brian Inglis, is now under intensive study by the Government. The Government will be announcing a detailed response as soon as practicable.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. Despite the Minister's earlier straight bat on the subject, I refer to recent news reports that the Government is seriously considering the sale of airport terminal facilities, and that Ansett Airlines joint-chairman, Sir Peter Abeles, has already privately offered to buy out Ansett's current leases for $100m. Are these reports true? If so, does this mean that the July 1986 national platform of the Australian Labor Party rejecting the concept of privatisation is no longer operative? On what basis does the Government suggest that the current market value or net present value of public instrumentalities should be assessed? Does the Minister agree that the sale of terminals to an existing airline operator would be likely to constitute a significant barrier to entry for new airlines in the event of a decision to deregulate the airline industry?

—Senator Alston said effectively that he did not expect me to answer this question, and he is right. I am not going to confirm or deny the latest piece of self-generated or received gossip that the media is running on this day or any other day.

—Is the Minister representing the Attorney-General aware of media speculation on the future of the Family Court which is causing concern in the community? When will the Government be able to announce a decision on this matter and so put an end to damaging speculation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have the following information from the Attorney-General on this matter. The Attorney has been concerned for some time with the need to give judges of the Family Court an opportunity to participate in other judicial work. He believes that this would benefit the judges by giving them a greater variety of work and that it would widen the field of potential recruits to the court. The Jackson Committee-the Advisory Committee to the Constitutional Commission on the Australian Judicial System-in a recent paper suggested a number of options for the future of the Family Court. These options included renewing the operation of the court by devolving work to registrars and magistrates and giving the judges of the court an opportunity to exercise a wider jurisdiction. The Jackson Committee saw these as leading to the opportunity to incorporate the Family Court as a division of the Federal Court.

ANSWER.PARA: The Attorney did raise for the consideration of judges of both the Family Court and the Federal Court the possibility of moving immediately to incorporating the Family Court as a division of the Federal Court. Following consideration of that proposal by the judges, the Attorney subsequently discussed at a meeting of most of the judges of the Family Court on 21 March a number of steps that might be taken immediately. The Attorney announced on 25 March that a number of proposals were being developed in consultation with the Family Court. These included increased powers for registrars, appointment of masters to deal with some of the less complex contested and other matters now handled by judges, possible wider jurisdiction for State magistrates in family law matters. Discussions are being held with Federal Court and Family Court judges about the possibility of wider jurisdiction for the Family Court in areas additional to family law. No doubt when those discussions are concluded and a decision has been made, we will tell anyone who is interested about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about the family law centre-another good idea at the time?
—Even Senator Durack.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment. I refer to the Minister's decision to reject the options put up by the technical working group for water management at the Ranger uranium mine at Jabiru in the Northern Territory. Bearing in mind the expertise of the working group, which consisted of representatives of the Northern Territory Department of Mines and Energy, Energy Resources of Australia and Ranger Mines, and the Office of the Supervising Scientist for the Alligator Rivers Region, what equally expert advice did the Federal Minister rely upon in rejecting the recommendations of the working group? Was it in fact the case that the Minister relied on purely political advice, aimed at grabbing the greenie vote in what may be an election year, when he decided to reject the working group's recommendations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that I am perhaps in a better position than Senator Ryan, who has only a representative role in this chamber, to answer that question since I was immediately involved in the decision with my colleague the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment, Mr Cohen, and I can answer accordingly from direct personal knowledge of that sequence of decision-making events. I unequivocally and absolutely reject the various premises of Senator Kilgariff's question, which pick up a rather florid and tawdry Press release that was issued by the purported Opposition spokesman on these matters, Senator Durack, a few days ago. The situation is that the Government did accept the technical and scientific advice from the Office of the Supervising Scientist as reflected in the conclusions of the technical working group. However, the concept of best practicable technology as involved in the environmental requirements for the Ranger mine involves not only the concept of technical and purely scientific factors but also the question of social factors.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government is obliged to have regard to social factors in applying the concept of best practicable technology to the water management regime. So much was implicitly acknowledged by the technical working group in itself indica-ting that the one in 10 option might be regarded, while no better in scientific and technical terms than the two years in five release option, nonetheless as being possibly more attractive because it did have regard to possible community concerns about this and the desirability of the community, particularly the Aboriginal com- munity, having time to become accustomed to the concept of a release regime, to find out more as to what was involved in it and as a result to be less likely to react adversely to it. Social factors to that extent were already implicit in the technical working group report.

The Government simply took that process one stage further by saying that, while we were prepared to accept the one in 10 option as a preli-minary response to the best practicable technology needs of water management, nonetheless we thought that it was very much worth further exploration as to whether there might be further techniques adopted or proposals developed which would reduce still further the probability of water release ever needing to be considered. It is on that basis that the Office of the Supervising Scientist is being requested, in consultation with the Ranger mine, to develop further environmentally acceptable and practicable options with a view to seeing whether we can reduce still further the probability of water release.

TALK.START.PARA: —Haven't you heard of King Canute?

—Will you stop rabbiting on over there? You know not what you are talking about. If the honourable senator knew anything about what he is talking about, I would be delighted to respond to him, but he wallows along in the wake, bobbing like a cork on the sea of events as they pass by, a helpless case. My colleague Senator Walsh interjects `krypton', a biologically inert gasbag, that is the best description. I do not want to pursue those matters further. We have a sensible understanding in the community at large about the balance of considerations that need to be involved in any sensible approach to water management at Ranger, and with some sensible further approaches to this by the Office of the Supervising Scientist and the mine management I believe that we will have a totally acceptable solution to this long-standing problem.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Finance. I ask him this question in the context of the release this morning in the Press of news of the Government's reform of the workers compensation Act as it applies to Commonwealth employees. I ask him whether under the reform common law is to be abolished absolutely. If so, what provisions are to be put in its place? Are there any provisions to prevent accidents happening in the work place to be enacted and are there any provisions to enable rehabilitation to take place under the new scheme?

—In response to the last part of the question, the legislation has not yet been drafted, so I cannot give a precise answer. It is the Government's general policy to both minimise accidents or work-caused disability and maximise the rehabilitation of people who may be so affected. In respect of the first part of the question, the policy is to remove from common law jurisdiction-to legislate to override common law, I suppose-the so-called pain and suffering provision of common law actions. I think that is absolutely essential, firstly, because pain and suffering is very difficult to determine, obviously, and secondly, it becomes a particular problem when we have both a medical profession and a judiciary in Australia so prone to make capricious and irrational judgments, as they do.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate and Minister representing the Minister Assisting the Treasurer on Prices. Is it a fact that the amount paid out by home buyers has risen from 18.3 per cent of family income at the time of the last election to 26.7 per cent now? Is it also a fact that in the same period monthly repayments on a $50,000 loan over 25 years have risen from $508 to $660, an increase of more than $35 a week? Is it a fact that there are now 157,607 people on public housing waiting lists, an increase of almost one-third since the Hawke Government came to office? What excuse does the Minister give for home ownership becoming so much less affordable under the Labor Government?

—I do not offer any excuse. The conditions of the Australian economy at present have created difficulties for all sections of the community. Until we can improve our national income those difficulties will continue to be felt in one way or another in certain parts of the community. The important thing for the Government is to try to alleviate the areas of greatest disability and those who suffer most from the circumstances of our incapacity to sell commodities overseas at the same prices as we did in the past. I ask the honourable senator to put the earlier part of the question on notice because it is a detailed question with five parts.
—I ask the Special Minister of State: Does he recognise the need to protect witnesses against organised crime? If so, what plans does he have to deal with the matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think common sense would inform honourable senators that when a law enforcement agency-in particular a joint task force established with the use of the skills of accountants in addition to those of police officers and so on-is pursuing an organised crime figure, a principal target, it may be that in order to get the sort of intelligence which is necessary either to prevent or disrupt some criminal activity or even to assemble admissible evidence in regard to that organised crime figure so that he can be arrested and brought before the courts, we need to offer to a person who can provide that sort of intelligence or evidence a guarantee of protection against violence or intimidation and even against threats of death.

ANSWER.PARA: In that situation it is vital to the operations of law enforcement agencies and, in particular, the National Crime Authority, for which I have responsibility, that facilities for the protection of witnesses who can provide such information be available. Quite clearly, the sort of information which is so vital is more likely to be forthcoming if that protection can be offered. Arrangements have to be put in place because non-custodial protection of that sort is very expensive and very resource-intensive both in cost and in manpower in that a number of people are required to undertake such protection. It is vital that we have a full discussion not only between elements within my own portfolio, such as the Australian Federal Police and the National Crime Authority, but also right across the various jurisdictions throughout Australia.

To that end I have written to the police and corrective services Ministers in order to seek the beginning of discussions as to how we might put such witness protection programs in place in a co-operative and collaborative way. I have also taken the opportunity in a courtesy call that I paid on the Joint Parliamentary Committee on the National Crime Authority to raise with that Committee the possibility that it might, in setting its agenda for the year, consider some sort of reflection and deliberation on the question of witness protection so that the Government may be helped in its deliberations by the work of that particular Committee. It is for that Committee to set its agenda, but I noted in its second report to the Parliament that witness protection was amongst the matters which it considered ought to be the subject of some review. I hope with that sort of program of consultation we will be able to move to a situation where the law enforcement authorities will be able, more securely, to offer the protection required by witnesses who can provide very good intelligence and even admissible evidence.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer the Minister to the well-known cartoon featuring the Prime Minister at his desk with a punk hair-do and filing his nails with a rasp which has as its caption: `Youth of Australia, Priority Two. Don't call us, we'll call you'. I remind the Minister that today only 12 of the 300 Ansett Priority One: Young Australia traineeships which were announced in 1985 are in place. I ask the Minister: Firstly, when can the remaining 288 trainees expect a call? Secondly, what action is the Government taking to remedy the failure of the Priority One scheme to generate private sector traineeships? Thirdly, are certain unions holding up the negotiations and thereby denying young Australians the opportunities a traineeship would offer? Lastly, with 75,000 more 15- to 24-year olds, including 64,200 more 15- to 19-year olds unemployed since Priority One commenced, what steps will the Government take to deal with this serious problem?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have the command of detail which would enable me to answer all the specific questions in that general question which the honourable senator has asked, nor is my numeracy adequate enough to cope with all those figures. I want that to be understood. I will certainly try to get the honourable senator a detailed answer on the question.

ANSWER.PARA: The process of negotiating traineeships has been a difficult one. It was difficult initially with some of the unions. I do not think there are any difficulties remaining with the unions. There are still difficulties remaining with management in a number of areas. I am not seeking to buy into a whose fault type argument in saying that. I think that is the reality, that is the essence of the problem currently. I will try to get the honourable senator an early answer to the detailed parts of the question.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Trade to the article on the front page of the Australian Financial Review of 30 March entitled `Trade tensions rise as US, UK move against Japan'. In that article, both the United Kingdom and the United States of America were considering, or had taken, punitive steps against Japan because of its trading policies. Can the Minister state what reactions the Australian Government has to these developments and what impact such steps could have for Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is too early to comment on the impact of what has happened in the United States stance. I know that the Ministry of International Trade and Industry has arranged a series of negotiations with the Americans regarding the announcement made by the United States Government. I do not think those talks have been resolved at this stage. However, the Government is highly critical of the protectionist regime which is increasingly adopted by the United States Government, confronted as it is with an enormous deficit and, it appears, an incapacity to take steps to restructure many of its industries, which are clearly uncompetitive with Japan.

ANSWER.PARA: This kind of deterioration in trade relations between two countries which are our major trading partners is a very serious matter. However, in Australia's case our major concern centres on coal and beef because they are our largest export items to Japan. We received assurances in January from the Japanese Government about coal and those assurances were repeated to Senator Evans, I believe, during his recent visit to Tokyo when he was told that trade was not being influenced by non-commercial factors. Also, in January, we received assurances that Japan had no intention of settling trade disputes with third countries at the expense of Australia. We place a very high value on these assurances and I personally have had communications with Japanese Ministers since January which confirm them.

On the question of beef, we have made strong representations to the Japanese Government about developments in the market which have favoured imports from the United States. We will seek to have those matters redressed during the post-1988 beef access negotiations which begin later this year. I also draw the honourable senator's attention to recent reports about increases in beef consumption in Japan and the incapacity of the domestic industry to meet those increases in demand. So there can be some optimism about those negotiations. To return to the point of the question, I do not think that we have quite seen the end of the negotiations about the United States Government's announcements, particularly on electronic components, but we will await with interest and concern the position taken by the United States.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I wish to point out to honourable senators that 24 questions were asked and answered today, which is by far the most in this session.

—On 2 April Senator Reid asked me about the development of the veterans' home care service program in the Australian Capital Territory. The current position is that officers of my department will meet the ACT Health Authority and Department of Territories officials on 9 April to discuss how the veterans' home care service program can be quickly implemented in the Australian Capital Territory. My departmental officers will also speak to the few organisations that currently provide these types of services to see what arrangements can be made for entitled veterans and their dependants. Senator Reid may also be aware that the Department of Territories has recently advertised for proposals for home and community care program funds to provide services which enable the frail aged and disabled to stay in their homes rather than move into inappropriate or premature residential care. My Department is hopeful that these funds, when allocated, will provide the infrastructure from which the veterans' home care service program can operate in the widest possible way.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I claim to have been misrepresented and seek leave to make a statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

—I raise a point of order, Mr President. It was my action in that regard that was incorrectly stated by Andrew Fraser in the Canberra Times article today. I did, in fact, oppose the Bill and I voted with my Party. I would be grateful if at some time in the future the Canberra Times would correct the error it has made.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I claim to have been misrepresented and I seek leave to make a personal explanation relating particularly to that matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to an article by Australian Associated Press which claimed that I had suggested in the Senate that high import costs were the major problems for Australian farmers. I draw the Senate's attention to the motion that I moved in this place:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The need for the Government to bring down the crippling interest rates, record levels of taxation and other costs which are devastating Australian farmers and small businesses in country towns.

I referred particularly to input costs, not import costs. I said that when the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) claimed that there was nothing else we could do for Australian farmers because their problems were related particularly to export prices, a child of 10 would understand that profits were what was left over after the costs had been paid and a significant rise in input costs had diminished dramatically the profits that farmers received. I referred particularly to the fact that the bright outlook for prices in the cattle and wool sectors was immediately being undermined by an average increase in costs of 7.6 per cent in the past year. I also made the point that these increases in costs were far above the levels being experienced by our overseas competitors. When I mentioned input costs I referred particularly to Australian levels of interest rates, the prime rate being in the range 18.5 per cent, the bank overdraft rate being very close to 20 per cent and the second hand machinery rate being 24 per cent from finance companies. I referred particularly to the input costs being driven up further by fringe benefits tax and the fact that farmers have not been allowed a flow-on of the full--

DEBATE.TITLE: LEMONTHYME AND SOUTHERN FORESTS (COMMISSION OF INQUIRY) BILL 1987

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the debate was interrupted for Question Time, the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan), who was then at the table, was asked whether the Government would accept the amendments put up by the Opposition on the basis of the strong recommendations from the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I acknowledge that what the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) has said is correct-that the response to the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills has been read into the record by the previous Minister at the table, the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan). Do I take it from the Minister's silence that he does not intend to answer that? Has the Government not come to grips with it?

TALK.START.PARA: —There is nothing more to say. The Government has taken on board the response of the Committee. No new point has been raised or drawn to the Government's attention. We have looked at it and made a decision and we want the Bill to proceed on the basis that I have indicated. Under those circumstances, there is nothing more to be added to the debate on this clause as far as we are concerned.

—As I have already drawn attention to the Minister's so-called record on civil liberties, he should find it very hard to sleep straight in bed at night if he thinks about his response. It is quite disgraceful that, on the grounds of expediency and expedition, he rides roughshod over the rights of citizens in an area as vital as their legal rights in terms of self-incrimination. I am appalled. How dare he call himself a civil libertarian and give me the answer that he just did.
—Now that the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans), a former Attorney-General, has returned to the chamber, perhaps he will be able to--
—I was just filling in for Senator Ryan. I am not running for cover.

—No, I want the Minister here to answer this question. We want to know what are the mechanics of enforcement of the Commission's purported right to compel State witnesses to appear before the Commission. What mechanisms does the Commonwealth intend to use?

—I do not have a detailed answer up my sleeve, but the normal mechanics for enforcement of orders made by bodies such as this pursuant to statutory powers are that, if the order is not responded to by the recipient of it, it is a matter of seeking the appropriate process through the courts. These things are not self-executing; they have to be enforced through the courts and that no doubt would be the course taken. It may well be that if this process were to be applied against a State, there would be some legal argument about the capacity of legislation of this kind to apply to a State. Of course, that is something that the Government has considered and we will meet that challenge should it arise.

—Given the acknowledgment that there could be a legal difficulty, and given that the Minister is steeped in the history of the law, I ask: Can the Minister give us a case in the history of the Federation of a previous attempt by the Commonwealth to force a State government to provide information to a Federal inquiry, as would be required under this legislation?

—I do not want to prolong this conversation, but there is no case of which I am aware in which provisions of the Royal Commissions Act have been applied, or in which they have been attempted to be applied, to the States. I am unable to answer whether there have been any ad hoc inquiries established over the years in respect of which the States have been brought within their ambit. There is a particular reason for doing so in this instance, which has been well articulated in the second reading speech and elsewhere. It is understood. It is an omission from the Royal Commissions Act, no doubt simply because the situation has not arisen before. It is an omission that we are now seeking to correct, for reasons that are well understood and need no further explanation.

—That was a question that I asked earlier and that the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan), who was then at the table, was unable to answer. I am delighted that, from his knowledge, the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans), who is now at the table, has been able to give us that answer. Before the Minister leaves the table, I really would like him to answer one last question, which is very interesting. Seeing that the Minister has already said that this is a precedent, can the Minister say whether the Government agrees as a matter of principle that royal commissions should have the power to require a witness to incriminate himself?

—The standard mechanism for dealing with this very difficult question, which does of course raise issues of principle, is that an executive inquiry of the status of a royal commission ought to be able to inquire fully and fearlessly and without inhibition or limitation on the matters within its investigative charter and, accordingly, that people ought not to be allowed to refuse questions that are properly relevant to that charter. However, the corollary of that, which as I recall has traditionally been accepted in relation to royal commissions, is that such evidence should not be able to be used in any subsequent criminal or other process against the witness in question. That is the trade-off that has traditionally been adopted in relation to Executive inquiries of that kind that are provided for in the Royal Commissions Act and are involved here. Of course it is anticipated-I hope this is understood-that it is highly unlikely, in the context of the present inquiry, which is about the proper management of forestry resources, that issues of self-incrimination will even remotely arise. So I do not believe, with the utmost respect, that people should get their knickers in a twist about this issue in the context of the Tasmanian inquiry, because it is highly unlikely, as a practical matter, that this would ever come to practical relevance.

—If that is the case, surely there is no argument at all about taking it out. If the ex-Minister is so satisfied that there is no need for it, we do not need it in the legislation. It is as simple as that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise some matters regarding clause 13 in relation to the operation of the Royal Commissions Act. Firstly, I seek from the Minister an assurance that, with the exception of those sections of the Royal Commissions Act which are provided for in section 6d (2) about the taking of evidence in private, it is intended under this legislation that all of the hearings of the Commission will be conducted in public.

SPEECH.PARA: We have already passed clause 10, which relates to sub-section 6d (2) of the Royal Commissions Act in accordance with clause 13, which is now before us. I seek the assurance that except where the matter before the Commission goes to the question of the financial position of any person or relates to the profits or financial position of any person-which is the purport of section 6d (2) of the Royal Commissions Act-all the hearings of the Commission are to be hearings in public. Bearing in mind that clause 13 (4) gives operation to section 6d of the Royal Commissions Act with the exception of sub-section (5), which goes to the derogation of its powers to take evidence in private, I seek the assurance that, other than on the financially sensitive information, it is intended that all of the hearings of the Commission will be public.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are limitations on any assurances that the Government can give to the extent that we are establishing an independent commission that will be making these decisions itself. I cannot believe that the policy which the Government would wish the Commission of Inquiry to follow would be otherwise than as Senator Puplick has indicated. The only justification I can foresee, as presently advised, for holding hearings in private would be commercial confidentiality. An inquiry of this nature, where matters of security, criminality or whatever are not involved, is essentially a public inquiry and a matter of public interest. I believe that only considerations of commercial confidentiality would justify private hearings. But essentially, it is a matter for the Commission itself, as I am sure Senator Puplick will appreciate.

—Senator Gareth Evans may be aware that there was some discussion on an earlier clause as to the provision of information to the Commission of Inquiry which has been sought by other persons under freedom of information legislation. Therefore, I put to Senator Evans the question: If the Commission of Inquiry were to call for, say, material on a scientific assessment or material which went to the question of correspondence between Federal and State authorities which had previously been denied under a freedom of information request but which was provided to the Commission of Inquiry in order to assist the Commission with an appreciation of scientific data or of matters which were in dispute, would that material provided to the Commission and referred to in public discussions and in public hearings of the Commission then equally, having been made available to the Commission-the Minister gave an assurance that he hopes that the Commission would operate in a public forum-if it is not financially sensitive material, as provided for in 6d (2) of the Royal Commissions Act, also thereby become public information?

—Again I can only say that it is essentially a matter for the Commission itself what it chooses to make public, either in the course of public hearings or in its final report and the associated evidence that is published. The Government is happy to leave that decision making to the Commission. It is obvious that there are quite different criteria that it may be appropriate to apply in the context of a freedom of information application, not least when there are Federal-State sensitivities involved in a particular matter. But those considerations are clearly not immediately relevant to the publication decisions that will be made by the Commission of Inquiry itself. Beyond that I do not think that I can usefully comment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister then tell me from where the Commission obtains independent authority to hold hearings which may not be public hearings? Clause 10 (4) of the Bill states:

SPEECH.PARA: Subject to subsection 6d (2) of the Royal Commissions Act 1902 in its application in accordance with section 13-
which we are now on-
hearings before the Commission shall be held in public.
Sub-section 6d (2) of the Royal Commissions Act states:

If any witness before a Royal Commission requests that his evidence relating to a particular subject be taken in private on the ground that the evidence relates to the profits or financial position of any person, and that the taking of the evidence in public would be unfairly prejudicial to the interests of that person, the Commission may, if it thinks proper, take that evidence in private, and no person who is not expressly authorized by the Commission to be present shall be present during the taking of that evidence.

The Minister says that this is a matter within the discretion of the independent Commission. I put it to him that the reading of clause 13 together with the reading of clause 10 (4) takes away from the Commission the capacity to hold any private hearings other than on the question of commercial sensitivity covered in section 6d (2) of the Royal Commissions Act.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I simply make the point that it is for the Commission itself rather than the Government to determine the application in particular circumstances of the rules that Senator Puplick has read out and which are, I think, a complete and accurate account of the rules that would govern the Commission. SPEECH.PARA: The other point I quickly make, lest there be any confusion about the question of documentary evidence, is that it is of course within the capacity of a royal commission, and this Commission, to gather evidence by means other than a hearing process. I hope that that has cleared up any further misunderstanding that may have been in some people's minds, if not in Senator Puplick's, about the way this will all work.

TALK.START.PARA: —Any claim for a hearing to be in private must be based on the tests of section 6d (2) of the Royal Commissions Act?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the chamber's attention to exactly what the Opposition has been trying to do here. TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to a question I asked on 26 March during previous debate in the Committee stage of this measure. I attempted to obtain from the Government the precise article of the Convention for the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage upon which the Government relies for its powers to enact this legislation. Senator Gietzelt responded to my request. He referred to Article 34 (a) of the Convention, which really does not tell us anything. Bearing in mind that in the Tasmanian dams case the High Court of Australia indicated that the acceptance by Australia of an obligation under an international convention suffices to establish the power of the Commonwealth to make a law to fulfil the obligation, I am asking the Government to identify the article in the Convention which imposes an obligation on the Government to enact this legislation, particularly clause 16.

—I agree with Senator Harradine that article 34 (a) of the World Heritage Convention is not particularly helpful in addressing this issue. That is the Federal clause, essentially, and it explains the interrelationship between the Commonwealth and the State. It does not go back to the basic obligation on which the legislation must primarily be based. That obligation is to be found in Articles 3, 4 and 5 (d) of the World Heritage Convention which place an obligation on parties to the Convention to identify natural heritage and cultural heritage as defined in the Convention. If we analyse the travaux preparatoires, the documents preparatory to the Convention, they show that the identification was clearly understood by all the participating parties as including the process of inquiry and report. This is the purpose of the inquiry being set up under this Bill. The chain of argument and authority clearly is there and it goes back to Articles 3, 4 and 5 (d), not Article 34 (a).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought that that may have been the response. We have one Minister saying one thing and another Minister saying another. I thought the Minister would refer to Articles 3, 4 and 5 (d). I have examined those Articles and can find nothing in them which would provide the power to the Parliament to do what clause 16 enables the Minister to do. Clause 16 imposes an obligation on people in Tasmania, for example, not to carry out any excavation works within the `protected area' except with the consent in writing of the Minister. This obligation is imposed on persons whether they act personally or through a servant or agent. Also prohibited is any other act prescribed for the purposes of this paragraph.
